title: How to Check a Child's Hair for Lice

methods.name: Wet Combing to Diagnose a Lice Infestation

steps.headline: Wash your child's hair.
steps.description: Be sure to use shampoo and conditioner. The resulting moisture at the root of your child's hair, where lice thrive, may temporarily prevent their movement along the scalp. Conditioner will also make it easier to comb through your child's hair. Use a comb containing gaps no more than 0.2mm.

steps.headline: Comb your child's hair.
steps.description: Use a wide-toothed comb to straighten out any tangles or knots in the hair.

steps.headline: Switch to a lice removal comb.
steps.description: Now that your child's hair is clean and straight, you can begin to inspect their scalp more closely for lice.

steps.headline: Make sure you'll be able to see.
steps.description: Have your child sit perfectly still. Use a room with good lighting, or sufficient natural light from outside. Drape a white-colored cloth across your child's shoulders while searching. This way if any lice fall off your child's head while searching, the lice can be collected and easily discarded. If necessary, have a flashlight or headlamp handy so that you can examine the roots more carefully. You may also want to have a magnifying glass on hand to be sure you don't miss anything.

steps.headline: Start at the scalp and brush out firmly to the ends of your child's hair.
steps.description: You can hold the brush in place with each stroke to systematically search for lice. This will allow you to thoroughly examine each section of your child's head. Pay extra attention to the area of the scalp around the ears and at the nape of the neck. Although lice can live anywhere on the scalp, these areas tend to be tell-tale regions during an infestation.

steps.headline: Check near the hair follicle, about 1/4-inch (6 mm) to 1/2-inch from the scalp, for eggs (called nits).
steps.description: Nits are about the size of a pinhead and are glued onto the hair shaft. They are oval-shaped and translucent in color when first laid, but turn brown as the embryo develops.

steps.headline: Inspect the comb's teeth after each stroke.
steps.description: Look for lice and their eggs (nits).

steps.headline: Understand what to look for.
steps.description: Adult lice are light brown and their bodies will be about the size of a sesame seed. Nits may be brown, yellow, or white. Closely examine the comb's teeth both during and after each comb stroke, using a magnifying glass if necessary. If examining under a blacklight, the nits will appear as light blue in color.

steps.headline: Rinse the comb under a faucet after each stroke or dislodge the lice using a piece of wet toilet paper.
steps.description: This will remove any lice that were picked up during combing. It will also wash away any dandruff your child might have, which can resemble lice nits.

steps.headline: Work over each region of your child's head at least once.
steps.description: It may be more effective to repeat this process, as lice can move around on the scalp.

methods.name: Dry Combing to Diagnose a Lice Infection

steps.headline: Comb through your child's hair.
steps.description: It may be helpful to detangle hair with a brush or comb first.

steps.headline: Use a fine-toothed lice comb.
steps.description: This process will be similar to wet-combing. If nits pose a problem to thorough combing, try soaking hair in a 3%-5% white vinegar bath prior to using the lice comb.

steps.headline: Trap lice.
steps.description: You might be able to pin lice against the comb using your fingers, but tweezers may be more effective. Some experts say that manually removing lice as described above may be more effective (though also more time consuming) than over-the-counter lice treatments.

steps.headline: Place any lice you find in a small cup of isopropyl (rubbing) alcohol.
steps.description: Lice can survive in water, and may escape if not properly dealt with after combing. You should also soak the combs used to find and catch lice in rubbing alcohol for at least one hour.

steps.headline: Be vigilant.
steps.description: If you have found lice and/or nits and removed them with a comb or tweezers, it is important to repeat the procedure on a daily basis. Eggs may take several days to hatch, so it's important to continue treatment and removal, even if it seems like the problem is getting better. Some experts recommend nightly lice inspection and removal and continued monitoring for two to three weeks after the initial treatment. While dry combing is an excellent way to detect lice, picking individual lice with tweezers can be a tiresome and time-consuming activity for both you and your child. Some experts recommend wet combing, as it allows you to quickly diagnose and partially treat the infection more efficiently. If your child has a hard time sitting still for prolonged periods, try doing lice inspection/removal with a movie or TV show on. Television may provide a welcome distraction for your child while you look for and remove lice and nits.

steps.headline: Wash your child's clothes and bedding.
steps.description: Even if your child doesn't show any signs or symptoms of a lice infection, if one of their friends has lice, it's best to take precautions.

steps.headline: Ask around.
steps.description: Find out from your child's school whether anyone in his or her grade has reported a lice inspection. You may want to ask other parents as well.

steps.headline: Look for signs and symptoms.
steps.description: Take note if your child or one of your child's friends engages in frequent head scratching or appears to have an itchy scalp or crawling sensations.

steps.headline: Do not let your child share combs, brushes, helmets, or hats with anyone.
steps.description: You may also want to advise your child to avoid touching couches, chairs, or pillows that a person with lice has used.

steps.headline: Check the rest of your family.
steps.description: If your child has lice, there's a good chance you or someone else in your home may have been exposed to lice. If you are manually removing lice from your child's head, wear rubber gloves or thoroughly wash your hands afterward, as lice have been known in some cases to live underneath a host's fingernails before spreading to the head.

steps.headline: Wash laundry frequently.
steps.description: Bedding, towels, hats, and recently worn clothes should be washed with hot, soapy water and put through a clothes dryer at 140 degrees Fahrenheit (60 degrees Celsius). You may also want to vacuum pillows and car seats, and store anything that can't be washed (like stuffed animals) in a sealed plastic bag for at least two weeks to ensure that any lice and unhatched eggs are dead.
